questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery. 

The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text:
Which of the statements given below regarding the muscle shown in the image are correct?
  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibres of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibres of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction and elevation of the scapula and they rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly.

Rhomboids minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. They are supplied by the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery.

Muscles involved in movements of the scapula are:

  • Protraction (forward movement): Serratus anterior and pectoralis minor are prime movers. Rhomboid muscles control the rate and range of movements. The upper part of the latissimus dorsi acts like a strap across the inferior scapular angle in protraction.
  • Retraction (backward movement): Middle trapezius and rhomboids.
  • Elevation: Trapezius, Levator scapulae and rhomboids. 
  • Depression: Usually gravity alone is sufficient for the depression of the scapula. When required, a part of the serratus anterior, pectoralis minor, and trapezius are used.
     

Appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations:

Muscle  Nerve Supply Action

Trapezius

 Accessory nerve

Elevation of the scapula, rotation of scapula during abduction of humerus above horizontal; middle fibers retract scapula; lower fibers depress the scapula

Latissimus dorsi

 Thoracodorsal nerve

Adduction, medial rotation, and extension of the arm at the glenohumeral joint

Levator scapulae

 Dorsal scapular nerve
Branches directly from anterior rami of C3 and C4

Elevation of the scapula

Rhomboid major and minor

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Elevation and retraction of the scapula

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Facial nerve A. Shrugging of shoulder
2. Spinal accessory nerve B. Taste from anterior two third of the tongue
3. Glossopharyngeal nerve  C. Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4. Mandibular nerve D. Chewing
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

1. Facial nerve B. Taste from anterior two third of the tongue
2. Spinal accessory nerve A. Shrugging of shoulder
3. Glossopharyngeal nerve  C. Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4. Mandibular nerve  D. Chewing

 

Chorda tympani nerve which is a branch of facial nerve carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. 

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes retraction of scapula, shrugging of the shoulder and overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior). Paralysis of trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of scapula becomes more prominent).

The glossopharyngeal nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. 

The mandibular nerve (V3) is responsible for chewing movements as it gives motor supply to muscles of mastication. It contains both sensory and motor fibers.

  • Sensory from
    • Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
    • Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
    • Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue
  • Motor to
    • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masster and temporalis)
    • Tensor tympani
    • Anterior belly of digastric
    • Mylohyoid

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve?
  1. Gluteus Medius
  2. Gluteus Minimus
  3. Tensor fascia lata
  4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor fascia lata are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve. Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis. 

The dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 rami give rise to the superior gluteal nerve. It is accompanied by superior gluteal vessels. This nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis and divides into superior and inferior branches. It supplies gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.

The dorsal divisions of the S1 and S2 rami give rise to the nerve to the piriformis. 

Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus act as the abductors of the hip joint. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. If the ipsilateral abductors are normal, the pelvis remains in a horizontal position. If the ipsilateral abductors are weak, then the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side. This is called positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

A recent update in Gray's Anatomy suggests that even the piriformis is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. But, the best answer combination amongst the given options is Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor fascia lata> Piriformis. 

The most common nerve branches to the piriformis are from the superior gluteal nerve and the ventral rami of S1 and S2.

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the gluteal region and their innervation

Muscles

Innervation

Gluteus maximus

 Inferior gluteal nerve

Gluteus medius and minimus

 Superior gluteal nerve

Pyriformis

 Nerve to pyriformis

Obturator internus, Gemellus superior

 Nerve to obturator internus

Quadratus femoris, Gemellus inferior

 Nerve to quadratus femoris

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation with a positive card test and an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits, suggests an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

Injury at the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve, leading to paralysis of flexor carpi ulnaris (loss of ulnar deviation) and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). It leads to hypothenar paralysis (lead to atrophy) and sensory loss. Also, flexor digitorum superficialis (supplied by median nerve) and extensor digitorum (supplied by the radial nerve) are still functional. Hence complete paralysis of the 3rd and 4th digits is not seen.  The positive card test is due to the weakness of palmar interossei leading to loss of adduction.

Ulnar nerve branches and supply: 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Injury to the Ulnar nerve:

  High lesion
(Elbow) 		 Low lesion 
(Wrist) 
Site of injury

Fracture/dislocation of the medial epicondyle

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Compression between the two heads of FCU

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy (Valgus deformity)

Wrist laceration/ slashing

Guyon's canal syndrome
Motor loss

Claw-hand deformity

Hypothenar & interosseous wasting

Loss of:

• Abduction & adduction of fingers
(Card test - Positive)
• Adduction of thumb
(Froment sign- Positive)
• Flexion of MCP joints

Weakness of wrist flexion (radial deviation)

Claw-hand deformity
(more pronounced)

Hypothenar & interosseous wasting

Loss of:

• Abduction & adduction of fingers
(Card test - Positive)
• Adduction of thumb
(Froment sign- Positive)
Sensory loss

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

No sensory loss over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

Other tests seen in ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

  • Claw hand deformity
  • Froment's sign positive
  • Wartenberg sign
  • Palmaris brevis sign

The image below shows a positive card test.

 

Wartenberg's sign: (Weakness of palmar interossei), Sensory loss Palmar and dorsal surface of the medial third of hand and medial 1 and a half fingers.

 

Other options: 

  • Option A: Radial groove - Radial nerve
  • Option D: Neck of humerus - Axillary nerve
  • Option B: Lateral epicondyle – May lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy after fracture but the incidence is less.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

A. Iliococcygeus
B. Pubococcygeus
C. Obturator internus
D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components:

  • Pubococcygeus
    • Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
    • Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
    • Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

Other options: 

The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are all except:

choices.text: Fundus and  body of Gall bladder

questions.solution:
Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum include the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum. 

Relations of the 3rd part of duodenum:

  • Posterior relations of 3rd part of duodenum include right ureter, right psoas major, right gonadal vessels, inferior vena cava and abdominal aorta (at the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery).
  • Anterior relations: Loops of jejunum, Root of mesentery and Superior mesenteric vessels.
  • Superiorly related to head of the pancreas and Inferiorly to loops of jejunum.

 

Note: Root of mesentery (containing Superior mesenteric vessels) lies anterior to the 3rd part of Duodenum. Hence, posterior relations of 3rd part of duodenum are the same as structures crossed by root of mesentery.

questions.text:
Arrange the following afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle from medial to lateral.
  1. General somatic
  2. General visceral
  3. Special somatic
  4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
From medial to lateral, the afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle are general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, special somatic. 

Embryologically, the continuous addition of neuroblasts to the mantle layer of the neural tube produces thickenings ventrally and dorsally - producing the basal and alar plates respectively. A longitudinal groove, called sulcus limitans, marks the boundary between the two.

Basal Plate  Alar plate 
Ventral thickening Dorsal thickenings
Give rise to motor nuclei- general visceral efferent nuclei, special visceral efferent of CN IX, X, and XII; and somatic efferent of XII Give rise to sensory nuclei CN V, VII, VIII, IX, X, inferior olivary nucleus, and mesencephalic nucleus of CN V
Forms the motor part of the spinal cord (ventral horns)

Forms the sensory part of the spinal cord (dorsal horns). 

The rhombic lip develops into the cerebellum and its nuclei.

questions.text:
Match the following muscles with their respective actions at the shoulder joint.

 

Muscle Action
A. Pectoralis major 1. Extension
B. Supraspinatus 2. Flexion
C. Infraspinatus 3. Lateral rotation
D. Latissimus dorsi 4. Abduction
questions.solution:
Muscles Actions
Supraspinatus Steadies the head of the humerus during movements, abduction of shoulder joint from 0-15°
Deltoid Abduction, anterior fibers - flexors and medial rotators, posterior fibers - extensors and lateral rotators
Infraspinatus Lateral rotator of the arm
Teres minor Lateral rotator of the arm
Teres major Adduction and medial rotation of the arm
Latissimus Dorsi Adduction, medial rotation, and extension of the arm
The long head of the triceps Extension of elbow joint
Pectoralis major Adduction, medial rotation, and flexion of the arm

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the para-axial mesoderm. The ribs are derived from the para-axial mesoderm.

During the third week of embryological development, the process of gastrulation occurs, which refers to the formation of the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm. This is followed by the formation of the notochord, which is the axial structure, which induces the formation of the neural tube above it. During the formation of the neural tube, some cells at the lateral border dissociate and form the neural crest cells, which is sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer.

After the formation of the notochord, which is the axial structure, the mesoderm on either side can be seen to be organized into three layers as follows:

1. Para-axial mesoderm - Thickened plate of the mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites, which have the following derivatives: 

  • Dermatome: Forms the segmental dermis of the skin
  • Myotome: Forms the skeletal muscle
  • Sclerotome: Forms the vertebral column and ribs

2. Intermediate mesoderm - Longitudinal strip of mesoderm that connects the para-axial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary (Option A) and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.

3. Lateral plate mesoderm - A thinner layer of mesoderm that lies laterally. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic coelom that gives rise to pericardial, pleural (Option C), and peritoneal cavities.

The neural crest cells also contribute to the formation of structures as follows:

In the trunk region, they form melanocytes, sensory ganglia (Option B), sympathetic and enteric neurons, Schwann cells, and adrenal medulla cells.
In the cranial region, they contribute to the craniofacial skeleton, neurons for cranial ganglia, satellite glial cells, and melanocytes.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

Related Pearl: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

Mesenchymal

All ganglions

Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull 

All enteric plexus

Dermis of the head and face

Schwann cells and Satellite glial cells

Odontoblasts (Dentine)

Adrenal Medulla

Arachnoid and Piamater 

Parafolliular C cells of Thyroid

Conotruncal septum in the heart

Melanoblast/Melanocytes (except Retinal Pigment Epithelium)

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi lunar in shape
The left adrenal gland is closely related with tail of pancreas and spleen
The adrenals are yellow on gross appearance
The adrenals are retroperitoneal in location

questions.solution:
Option A is false as the right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar/crescent shaped.

The adrenal glands, also called the supra-renal glands, are endocrine glands which are located at the upper pole of each kidney. They are grossly yellow in appearance and are retroperitoneal in location. Both glands are surrounded by areolar tissue and perirenal fascia. The following are the key differences between the right and the left adrenal glands and their relations:

  Right Adrenal Gland Left Adrenal Gland
Shape Pyramidal or triangular Semi-lunar or crescenteric
Parts  Apex and base Upper end and lower end
Superior relation Bare area of liver Spleen
Inferior relation Right kidney Left kidney and left supra-renal vein
Anterior relation IVC, bare area of liver Stomach and tail of pancreas with splenic artery
Posterior relation Right crus of diaphragm, right kidney Left crus of diaphragm, left kidney
Medial relation Coeliac ganglion Coeliac ganglion
Lateral relation Liver Stomach

Each gland is supplied by:

  • Superior suprarenal artery - branch of the inferior phrenic artery.
  • .Middle suprarenal artery - branch of the abdominal aorta.
  • Inferior suprarenal artery - branch of the renal artery.

Each gland has one draining vein.

  • The right suprarenal vein drains into the IVC.
  • The left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein.

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is?
questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the stem of the lateral sulcus lies under it.

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

The surface of the cerebrum consists of folds called gyri separated by fissures called sulci. The lateral sulcus, also called the Sylvian Fissure, is present on the infero-lateral surface of each cerebral hemisphere and separates the frontal lobe from the temporal lobe. The lateral sulcus consists of a stem which divides into three rami, which are, the anterior horizontal, anterior ascending, and the posterior rami.

The structures lying deep to the pterion are:

  • The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery
  • The middle meningeal vein
  • The stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure)

The bone in this area is thin and an injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: Given below is an illustration of a transverse section of the heart. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the sub-aortic curtain. It is also called the trigonum fibrosum sinistrum.

The fibrous skeleton of the heart is formed by fibrous tissue that is continuous between the atrio-ventricular and arterial orifices. They exist to keep the valves competent, allow attachment of cardiac musculature, and act as an insulating layer for the conducting system of the heart. The fibrous rings of importance are:

  • The atrioventricular fibrous rings - existing in a figure of 8 configuration, connecting the atria, ventricles and the membranous part of the interventricular septum.
  • The trigonum fibrosum dextrum - between the atrioventricular rings and the aortic ring.
  • The trigonum fibrosum sinistrum - between the mitral valve and the aortic valve.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as A.
questions.solution:
The arrow-marked structure in the given image is the terminal bronchiole. It can be identified by the absence of cartilage, which would be present in the bronchus, and the presence of cilia and stratified columnar epithelium, which would not be seen in respiratory bronchioles and alveolar sac.

The following is a summary of the intrapulmonary passages:

Trachea → Main Bronchi → Lobar Bronchi → Segmental Bronchi → Terminal Bronchiole → Respiratory Bronchiole → Alveolar Duct → Alveolar Sac → Alveoli

Bronchi and bronchioles can be distinguished by the presence of cartilage and glands in the bronchi which are not present in the bronchioles.

Terminal bronchioles represent the most distal parts of the conducting passage. Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. Terminal bronchioles contain cilia and stratified columnar epithelium, whereas respiratory bronchioles contain few or no cilia, and simple cuboidal epithelium. Another differentiating point between the two is that terminal bronchioles would not communicate with the alveoli but respiratory bronchioles would have a communication with the alveoli.

Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli. 

A: Terminal Bronchiole, B: Respiratory Bronchiole, C: Alveolar Sac, D: Alveolar Duct

The coloured strips in the following illustration represent the location of different cells/structures in the trachea and bronchial tree.

Note - The image in the question has been updated for better clarity

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls:

i. Anterior wall

ii. Roof

iii. Floor

iv. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominus muscle contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal walls.

The boundaries of the inguinal canal walls are as follows:

  • Anterior wall: Formed by the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Roof: Formed by the arched fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • Floor: Formed by the grooved upper surface of the Abdomen and Pelvis inguinal ligament.
  • Posterior wall: Consists of the transversalis fascia and conjoint tendon (the lowest fibres of the transverses abdominis muscle fuse with the lowest fibres of the internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon).

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer?
questions.solution:
The image shows a histological section of the adrenal gland and the layer marked is the outermost layer, ie, the zona glomerulosa, which secretes the mineralocorticoid - aldosterone, responsible for sodium and water retention.

Based on structure and function, the adrenal cortex has three zones, which from outer to inner, are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) - which acts in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system (RAAS) and acts at the distal convoluted tubule and the collecting ducts favouring sodium and water retention and potassium excretion.
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (cortisol and corticosterone) - which has multiple functions that include metabolic effects which induce hyperglycemia inducing gluconeogenesis (Option A) and mediates anti-inflammatory and immunosuppresive effects by interacting with the cells of the immune system (Option D).
  • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids (dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, estrogens, and glucocorticoids) (Option C)

Related Pearl: Secretion of Adrenal Hormones by the different Zones of the Adrenal Cortex and Adrenal Medulla

Adrenal Cortex

Adrenal Medulla

Zona glomerulosa(15%)

Mineralocorticoids

Aldosterone

Deoxycorticosterone

Norepinephrine

Epinephrine

Dopamine

Zona fasiculata (50%)

Glucocorticoids

Cortisol

Corticosterone

Zona reticularis(7%)

Androgens:

  • DHEA
  • Androstenedione

questions.text: A patient's right hip drops when he takes the right foot off the ground. Which of the following would not be involved in the patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with dropping of the right hip on lifting the right foot off the ground, has a positive Trendelenburg’s sign. The sciatic nerve would not be involved.

A positive Trendelenburg's sign is seen in the paralysis of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, both of which are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. In the scenario mentioned, since the patient has dropping of the hip on the right side, the structures on the left side would be affected.

Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus: 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground,  making it the unsupported side,  gluteus medius and minimus muscles on the opposite side, which is the supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis on the unsupported side sinks when the patient lifts the foot off the ground. This causes the patients to have a characteristic lurching gait.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the anomaly shown below?

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistance of prechordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.solution:
The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which occurs due to the persistence of pluripotent cells of the primitive streak in the sacrococcygeal region.

During the third week of embryological development, the process of gastrulation occurs, which refers to the formation of the three germ layers. These germ layers are formed from the primordial germ cells of the epiblast, which are pluripotent. The process begins with the formation of the primitive streak on the epiblast, which develops into the primitive node in the cranial region, and a primitive pit. The cells from the epiblast, migrate towards the primitive streak and invaginate into the primitive pit and organizes itself into cells arranged in three layers, which eventually develop into ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The prechordal plate simply refers to the cells that have invaginated in the cranial region.

Sacrococcygeal teratomas occur due to remnants of pluripotent cells from the primitive streak due to defective migration of the cells (Option B). As these cells are from the epiblast, teratomas contain tissues from all germ layers which may include skin, hair, cartilage and bone (Option C). These tumors are benign in nature (Option D), but may rarely become malignant. If they occur in the cranial end of the primitive streak, they form oro-pharyngeal teratomas (as shown below), whereas if they occur in the caudal end of the primitive streak in the coccygeal region, they are called sacro-coccygeal teratomas.

questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked structure.
questions.solution:
The arrow marks the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk. 

The image shows a cross section of a cadaver at the T5 vertebral level. This corresponds anteriorly to the level of the sternal angle, and is also the level of division between the superior and inferior mediastinum.

At this level, the other structures visible are:

  • The origin and termination of the arch of aorta. The descending aorta can be identified to the left of the oesophagus. The arch of the aorta (Option D) would be visible at the T3-T4 cross sectional level.
  • The superior vena cava (Option B), just lateral to the origin of the aorta, which can visually differentiated from the aorta based on the wall thickness. At this level, it penetrates the right atrium.
  • The bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk.
  • The left and right main bronchi. The carina (Option A) is not visible as the trachea bifurcates more proximally at the T4 level. 

Related Pearl: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum

  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thoracic duct
  • Thymus
  • Vessels-
    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Roots of great vessels
    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Esophagus
  • Vagus nerve
  • Azygos vein
  • Hemiazygos vein

questions.text: What is the role of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the subthalamic nucleus, which is a part of the basal ganglia and is concerned with motor function.

The basal ganglia refers to the mass of grey matter located within the cerebral white matter and is responsible for a number of coordinated functions including the control of extra-pyramidal pathways for motor coordination. There are two major pathways involved which are, the direct and indirect pathways.

The direct pathway stimulates the cortex to produce movement, whereas the indirect pathway inhibits it. The striatal activity in the direct pathway is mediated by D1 dopamine receptors and in the indirect pathway by D2 dopamine receptors. The subthalamic nucleus is a part of the indirect pathway. A lesion at subthalamic nuclei leads to loss of inhibitory effect of the indirect pathway resulting in dopaminergic overactivity responsible for features of hemiballismus.

Other Options:

Option B: Reward-punishment is associated with the prefrontal area and the dopaminergic connections linked to it from the ventral tegmental area.

Option C: Judgement is controlled by the frontal lobe.

Option D: Memory is controlled by the hippocampus.

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

Substantia nigra

  • Vascular>degenerative 
Athetosis Basal ganglia- Globus Pallidum Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
  • Vascular 
  • Degenerative 
  • Infiltrative

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve?
  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accesorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
From the given list, the muscles supplied by the lateral plantar nerve are the flexor digitorum accesorius and the first interossei.

The sole of the foot is supplied by the medial and lateral plantar nerves which are both branches of the tibial nerve.

All the muscles of the sole of the foot are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve, except for the following four muscles which are supplied by the medial plantar nerve:

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum brevis
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical

The sensory supply of the sole of the foot is as shown in the illustration below.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers as shown below:

1st layer: It consists of the abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis and abductor digiti minimi.

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It consists of the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: The marked structure sends efferents to which nucleus of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given coronal section of the brain is the fornix. The fornix carries associations from the hippocampus to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus via the mamillary bodies.

The Papez circuit is a part of the limbic system concerned with the control of emotional behaviour and memory. 

It consists of the following structures, which can be remembered using the given mnemonic:

  • Hippocampus (He)
  • Mamillary body (Man)
  • Anterior thalamus (Ate)
  • Cingulate gyrus (Cat)

(Mnemonic-He Man Ate Cat)

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: On neurologic examination, a patient is not able to identify an object but is able to recognize the object from its texture, colour and pattern. Which of the following is likely to have been affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests that the patient has visual agnosia and the likely site of involvement would be the inferior temporal lobe.

  • Agnosia refers to the inability to visually identify objects and is also called optic aphasia. According to De Jong, visual agnosia is further classified into:
    • Apperceptive visual agnosia - the visual image appears distorted to the patient and hence they are unable to recognise it. This occurs due lesions in the parieto-occipital region
    • Associative visual agnosia - inability to visually identify objects in the absence of visual impairment, with ability to identify the object using other sensory modalities (as suggested in the scenario). This occurs due to lesions of occipito-temporal junction, which is present in the inferior temporal lobe. Prosopagnosia is a type of associatetive visual agnosia which refers to the inability to visually identify faces. 

The occipital lobe acts as the primary visual area and a lesion in this region would result in cortical blindness and achromatopsia, which is the inability to visualise colour. In the given scenario, as the patient is also able to identify colour, it indicates that the occipital lobe (Option A) is unaffected and (hence inferior temporal lobe is the better answer). 

Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by a perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. In the given scenario, the patient is able to recognize the object from its texture and pattern which indicates that stereognosis is intact. Loss of this ability is known as astereognosis which occurs in lesions of the superior parietal lobule (Options B and C) and dorsal column pathways.

Related Pearl: Brodmann areas

Area of the Brain(Brodmann) Location

In the posterior parts of superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri
5 and 7 - Sensory association area Superior parietal lobule
8 - Frontal eye field Posterior part of middle frontal gyrus, anterior to the facial area of the precentral gyrus
44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

 Remaining part of the medial and superolateral surfaces of the occipital lobe
28 - Primary olfactory area Anterior part of the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus
43 - Gustatory(taste) area Inferior part of the parietal lobe, posterior to the general sensory area of the mouth

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: Apocrine glands are present in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Apocrine glands are present in the axilla.

Exocrine glands can be classified into three subtypes, based on the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells:

  1. Apocrine 
  2. Merocrine
  3. Holocrine

In apocrine glands, the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. Examples of apocrine glands are :

  • Secretion of milk fat by mammary glands
  • Atypical sweat glands in the axilla, perianal region, periumbilical skin, mons pubis.
  • Ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands

Apocrine glands are large glands found in the dermis or subcutaneous fat. They are a type of sweat gland. It consists of a basal secretory coil followed by a straight duct that opens into the pilary canal above the duct of the sebaceous gland. In hairless skin, it directly opens onto the skin surface. 

Apocrine activity is minimal before puberty, after which it is androgen-dependent and responsive to emotional stimuli. It is controlled by adrenergic nerves and is sensitive to adrenaline and noradrenaline. The secretion is initially sterile and odorless, but it undergoes bacterial decomposition to generate odorous and musky compounds. Obstruction of apocrine sweat ducts and associated upper hair follicles in the axillae, breast areolae, and pubic region, mainly in women, is thought to cause Fox–Fordyce disease. It is also implicated in the causation of a painful, occasionally debilitating condition called hidradenitis suppurativa.

The given image shows an illustration of apocrine secretion.

In merocrine glands, the secretions are initially packed into membrane-bound vesicles, shifted to the cell surface, and poured out by exocytosis. The cell remains intact. The stimulus for secretion is predominantly by raised intracellular calcium. It is the most commonly seen mechanism of exocrine secretion.

An example of the merocrine gland is the simple/typical sweat glands of the skin. An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

In holocrine glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion, and the secretion is poured commonly into an adjacent hair follicle. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands. A few examples of sebaceous glands are:

  • Montgomery's glands of nipples
  • The inner surface of prepuce, clitoris, and labia minora
  • Meibomian glands - palpebral tarsal glands

An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

Related Pearl: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature

Apocrine sweat gland

Eccrine sweat gland

Activity

Active at puberty

Throughout life

Opening on the surface

Around hair shaft

Through sweat pores

Function

Provides peculiar odour

Maintains temperature

Nervous control

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are adrenergic

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are cholinergic

Secretions

Viscid with lipids and proteins

Watery with salts

Related Pearl: Fox-Fordyce disease

Fox Fordyce disease, also known as Apocrine Miliaria, is characterized by intensely pruritic, white pearly papules in apocrine areas. It most commonly involves axilla, then areolae. It is commonly seen in women (90%).

The condition occurs as a result of apocrine sweat duct occlusion by aggregates of epithelial cells of the apocrine or apoeccrine secretory cells. The earliest pathological sign is a small vesicle in the apocrine duct.

Later, the apocrine glands are seen to be enlarged, and as a consequence of repeated inflammatory events, perifollicular xanthomatosis with perifollicular foam cells expressing CD68 may develop.

Treatment:

First-line

  • Topical or intralesional steroids
  • Topical clindamycin lotion
  • Topical retinoids

Second line

  • Ultraviolet light
  • Oral retinoids

Third line

  • Surgery

This should not be confused with Fordyce spots or Fordyce disease which is due to ectopic sebaceous glands.

Image: Fox-Fordyce disease of the axilla

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
The left inferior phrenic vein is a tributary of the inferior vena cava (IVC).

From inferior to superior, the following vessels are direct tributaries of the IVC:

  • Common iliac veins (left and right common iliac veins merge to form the IVC)
  • Median sacral vein
  • Four pairs of lumbar veins
  • Right gonadal vein
  • Renal veins (both left and right)
  • Right supra-renal vein
  • Hepatic veins
  • Inferior phrenic veins (both left and right)

Other Options:

Option B: The left supra-renal vein drains into the left renal vein.

Option C: The left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein.

Option D: The right ascending lumbar vein joins the subcostal vein on the right side to form the azygos vein. The left ascending lumbar vein joins the subcostal vein on the left side to form the hemi-azygos vein.
